edge: The film 'There Will Be Blood' is a directorial work by Paul Thomas Anderson, who is also known for other films such as 'Magnolia' and 'Punch-Drunk Love'.
Daniel Day-Lewis played the character of Daniel Plainview in 'There Will Be Blood'.
The film 'There Will Be Blood' is based on the novel 'Oil!' by Upton Sinclair.
Author Upton Sinclair wrote the novel 'Oil!' on which 'There Will Be Blood' is based.
At the beginning of the film, Daniel Day-Lewis's character, Daniel Plainview, is a silver miner.
As the story progresses, Daniel Plainview transforms into an oilman in search of wealth during Southern California's oil boom.
The story is set during the late 19th and early 20th centuries, a time when Southern California experienced an oil boom.
Actor Paul Dano played the character of H.W., who is later revealed to be Daniel Plainview's son, in 'There Will Be Blood'.
Actor Kevin J. O'Connor played the character of Leviticus 'Levy' Baines, a close associate of Daniel Plainview, in 'There Will Be Blood'.
Actor Ciarán Hinds played the character of Abel Rothschild, a wealthy oil magnate, in 'There Will Be Blood'.
Actor Dillon Freasier played the character of H.W.'s son, who is later revealed to be Daniel Plainview's grandson, in 'There Will Be Blood'.
In 1911, Daniel is approached by Paul Sunday, a young man who tells him of an oil deposit in Little Boston.

Daniel visits the Sundays' property in Little Boston and meets Paul's identical twin brother Eli, a preacher. Daniel attempts to purchase the farm from the Sundays at a bargain price under the ruse of using it to hunt quail, but his motives are questioned by Eli, who knows the land has oil.

In exchange for the property, Eli demands $10,000 for his church. An agreement is made and Daniel acquires all the available land in and around the Sunday property, save for one holdout, William Bandy.
Eli knows the land has oil.
An accident kills one worker.
A gas blowout deafens H.W. And destroys the drilling infrastructure.
When Eli publicly demands the money still owed to him, Daniel beats him.
A man arrives at Daniel's doorstep claiming to be his half-brother, Henry.
Later that night H.W. Sets fire to their house, intending to kill Henry.
Standard Oil offers to buy out Daniel's local interests, but Daniel refuses and instead strikes a deal with Union Oil to build a pipeline.
Bandy's ranch remains an impediment.

In 1927, H.W. asks his father to dissolve their partnership so that he can move to Mexico with Mary and start his own drilling company. Daniel angrily mocks H.W.'s deafness before revealing his true origins and disowning him as his son. Daniel's anger towards H.W. stems from H.W.'s decision to leave their partnership and start his own drilling company with Mary.
In 1927, H.W. marries Paul and Eli's sister Mary. Daniel is initially angered by H.W.'s decision to leave their partnership and start his own drilling company with Mary.
Daniel agrees on the condition that Eli denounce his faith to partner with the church in drilling Bandy's property. Daniel reveals that he has already drained the property of oil by capture.

In the bowling alley of his mansion, Eli visits a drunken Daniel. Their relationship is strained due to Daniel's condition that Eli denounce his faith to partner with the church in drilling Bandy's property.
Many have seen Daniel Plainview's 'I have a competition in me' speech as important when analyzing the film from the perspective of its commentary on the nature of capitalism and greed.
The film has been looked upon as a commentary on the inherent national presence of capitalism and greed in America.
David Denby of The New Yorker described the film as being about 'the driving force of capitalism as it both creates and destroys the future'.

'this movie is about the vanishing American frontier. The thrown-together buildings look scraggly and unkempt, the homesteaders are modest, stubborn, and reticent, but, in their undreamed-of future, Wal-Mart is on the way.'
James Christopher of The Times viewed the film as 'a biblical parable about America's failure to square religion and greed.'
Others have noted themes of faith, religion, and family.
Anderson changed the title of his adapted screenplay from Oil! to There Will Be Blood because he felt 'there's not enough of the book to feel like it's a proper adaptation'
Anderson contacted Schlosser and adapted the first 150 pages of Oil! into a screenplay
Research trips to museums dedicated to early oilmen in Bakersfield assisted Anderson in the development of the screenplay
Anderson had an existing screenplay about two fighting families, but struggled with it and soon realized it was not working

Anderson stated that the line in the final scene, 'I drink your milkshake!', was paraphrased from a quote by Fall during his testimony in the Teapot Dome scandal investigation.
Anderson found it fascinating to see the word 'milkshake' among all this official testimony and terminology during the Teapot Dome scandal investigation.
Anderson mentioned that Fall spoke before a Congressional investigation into the 1920s oil-related Teapot Dome scandal.
Anderson revealed that Fall's quote was paraphrased in the final scene of something.
Anderson disclosed that Fall was a former U.S. Senator from New Mexico during his testimony in the Teapot Dome scandal investigation.

An article published in the Case Western Reserve Law Review suggested that the actual source of the paraphrased quote may instead have been remarks made by Domenici during a debate over drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.

An article published in the Case Western Reserve Law Review suggested that Domenici's remarks during a debate over drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge may have been the actual source of the paraphrased quote.

The article published in the Case Western Reserve Law Review revealed that Domenici was a Senator from New Mexico during his remarks made during a debate over drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.
The oil is underground.
The oil is going to be drilled and come up.
Here is a giant reservoir underground.
Just like a curved straw, you put it underground and maneuver it,
Your little child wants the milk shake, and they sit over here in their bedroom where they are feeling ill,
and they just gobble it up from way down in the kitchen,
You don't have to take it up to the bedroom. This describes the actual drilling that is taking place.

According to Joanne Sellar, one of the film's producers, the film was difficult to finance because "the studios didn't think it had the scope of a major picture".[19] It took two years to acquire financing for the film.[20] For the role of Plainview's 'son', Anderson looked at people in Los Angeles and New York City, but he realized that they needed someone from Texas who knew how to shoot shotguns and 'live in that world'.[18] The filmmakers asked around at a school and the principal recommended Dillon Freasier. They did not have him read any scenes and instead talked to him, realizing that he was the perfect person for the role.[18]

Inspiration for Daniel Day-Lewis's character building process came from studying documentaries on director John Huston, an important influence on Wes Anderson's film 'The Treasure of the Sierra Madre', which was a source of inspiration for Day-Lewis.
Daniel Day-Lewis's character building process involved starting with his voice, as he received recordings from the late 19th century to 1927 and a copy of 'The Treasure of the Sierra Madre'.

While writing the script, Day-Lewis would put the film 'The Treasure of the Sierra Madre' on before he went to bed at night, which was a source of inspiration for his role as Sinclair in 'There Will Be Blood'.
'The Treasure of the Sierra Madre' is about greed and ambition and paranoia and looking at the worst parts of yourself, as mentioned by Wes Anderson.
Daniel Day-Lewis studied photographs and letters from laborers in preparation for his role as Sinclair, which was loosely based on oil tycoon Edward Doheny, as mentioned.
Wes Anderson tried to shoot the script for 'There Will Be Blood' in sequence with most of the sets on the ranch and in Los Angeles.
The interior mansion scenes were filmed at Greystone Mansion in Beverly Hills.
Greystone Mansion was the former real-life home of Edward Doheny Jr., a gift from his father, Edward Doheny.
Scenes filmed at Greystone involved the careful renovation of the basement's two-lane bowling alley.

Anderson said it was 'a particular situation, because it was so narrow that there could only be a very limited number of people at any given time, maybe five or six behind the camera and then the two boys.'
Day-Lewis later broke a rib in a fall during filming.
Anderson dedicated the film to Robert Altman, who died during editing.
After initially agreeing to score the film, Greenwood had doubts and thought about backing out, but Anderson's reassurance and enthusiasm for the film convinced him to continue.
Anderson gave Greenwood a copy of the film and three weeks later he came back with two hours of music recorded at Abbey Road Studios in London.
Concerning his approach to composing the soundtrack, Greenwood said to Entertainment Weekly:'

Although Greenwood mentions 'not necessarily just making period music', it is clear that classical music falls under the category of period music. However, what distinguishes them is their purpose - while period music is traditionally created for that specific time period, classical music can be heard in various contexts beyond its historical origin.

Period music typically features traditional orchestral sounds as Greenwood explains that these sounds are 'coming from very old technology' and can be both unsettling and slightly sinister due to their unfamiliarity in contemporary contexts.

node_2: johannes brahms's violin concerto in d major
edge: Greenwood mentions that the third movement ('Vivace Non Troppo') of Johannes Brahms's Violin Concerto in D Major is featured in his score. This indicates a specific work by the classical composer, Brahms.
Similarly, Greenwood mentions that Arvo Pärt's 'Fratres' is also featured in his score. This highlights a specific classical composition by the Estonian composer, Pärt.
some critics were skeptical of labeling the film as a masterpiece, but others praised it highly

edge: Schickel described the film as a 'mesmerizing meditation on the American spirit'
Schickel praised Daniel Day-Lewis' performance as 'astonishing'
Schickel ranked the film at #9 on his list of Top 10 Movies of 2007

node_2: mean and noble, angry and secretive, hypocritical and more than a little insane in its aspirations
edge: Schickel described the American spirit portrayed in the film as 'mean and noble, angry and secretive, hypocritical and more than a little insane in its aspirations'
No Country for Old Men, filmed in the same area of Texas, is a 'great' and 'perfect' film

node_2: lack of women or any reflection of ordinary society
edge: The film lacked women or reflections of ordinary society, as noted by Roger Ebert
Roger Ebert referred to the film's 'imperfections'
The film's characters were unbending, and its relentlessness was noted by Roger Ebert
Mick LaSalle criticized the scenes between Day-Lewis and Dano as degenerating into a 'ridiculous burlesque'

Carla Meyer of the Sacramento Bee, who gave the film the same star rating as Ebert, opined that the final confrontation between Daniel and Eli marked when the work 'stops being a masterpiece and becomes a really good movie. What was grand becomes petty, then overwrought.'

Several months after LaSalle's initial review of the film, he reiterated that while he still did not consider There Will Be Blood to be a masterpiece, he wondered if its 'style, an approach, an attitude... might become important in the future.'
Since 2008, the film has been included in the book 1001 Movies You Must See Before You Die and every revised edition released afterwards.
Total Film placed it at number three in their list of the 50 best movies of Total Film's lifetime.

In The Guardian, journalist Steve Rose ranked it the 17th best arthouse film of all time, and in a separate 2019 ranking a panel of four Guardian journalists ranked it the best film of the 21st century.
The film was on the American Film Institute's 10 Movies of the Year; AFI's jury said:

edge: The film was on the American Film Institute's 10 Movies of the Year.

node_2: one of american film's modern masters
edge: Paul Thomas Anderson's epic poem of savagery, optimism and obsession is a true meditation on America.

node_2: a career defined by transcendent performances
edge: Daniel Day-Lewis creates a character so rich and so towering, that "Daniel Plainview" will haunt the history of film for generations to come.
The film drills down into the dark heart of capitalism, where domination, not gain, is the ultimate goal.
In December 2009, Peter Travers of Rolling Stone chose the film as the #1 film of the decade,

node_2: appeared on many critics' top ten lists of the best films of 2007
edge: The film appeared on many critics' top ten lists of the best films of 2007.

node_2: ranked the decade's best film on five of them
edge: Review aggregator site Metacritic, when comparing over 40 'top ten of the decade' lists from various notable publications, found There Will Be Blood to be the most mentioned, appearing on 46% of critics' lists and being ranked the decade's best film on five of them.

In the beginning of the film, Daniel Plainview's character displays some similarities to a Horatio Alger story with his humble beginnings as a gold miner. However, their paths diverge drastically as Plainview becomes increasingly ruthless and amoral in pursuit of wealth.

node_2: horatio alger story gone horribly wrong
edge: Actor Daniel Day-Lewis' portrayal of Daniel Plainview transforms the classic Horatio Alger success story into a dark and chilling tale.
The film, set in the early 1900s, provides an evocative and detailed portrayal of this time period.
The film explores the complex relationship between the American ethos of rugged individualism and its effects on characters like Daniel Plainview.

edge: Paul Thomas Anderson's camera work is integral to the film's hypnotic and captivating style.

For a huge picture, there will be blood is exquisitely intimate, almost a collection of sketches. And when the votes were all in, by a nose, there will be blood stood alone at the top of the decade, its straw in the whole damn cinema's milkshake.
In 2016, it was voted the #3 best film of the 21st century as picked by 177 film critics from around the world.

The February 2020 issue of New York Magazine lists There Will Be Blood alongside Citizen Kane, Sunset Boulevard, Dr. Strangelove, Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid, The Conversation, Nashville, Taxi Driver, The Elephant Man, Pulp Fiction, In the Bedroom, and Roma as 'The Best Movies That Lost Best Picture at the Oscars.'
